playlist.title: Going Green
playlist.creator: OETA
playlist.annotation: Oklahoma News Report Going Green Feature Category

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Recycling
track.annotation: Between Thanksgiving and New Year’s Day, the EPA estimates that Americans generate two billion pounds of extra garbage. This year, a coalition of groups is working hard to keep that extra trash out of landfills.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Farm Efficiency
track.annotation: During this economic downturn, farmers are looking to improve their efficiency and reduce costs. At the Tulsa Farm Show, thousands of farmers from across Oklahoma and surrounding states learned how to find sustainable and energy-efficient ways to turn their farms into “green” operations.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Christmas Lights
track.annotation: LED lights are the hottest trend in holiday decorations. The lights are environmentally-friendly, and they use much less energy.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Energy Rebates
track.annotation: Schools and municipalities are looking for ways to shrink their energy bills. Some of them are getting help from a power company.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Owasso Trees
track.annotation: For many families, having the smell of a freshly-cut Christmas tree makes the holidays extra special. But actually picking out the right tree and cutting it yourself can create a family tradition for a lifetime.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Tulsa Sustainability
track.annotation: Changes are underway in Tulsa as part of that city's sustainability efforts. Some changes are simple, such as flipping a switch to cut energy use, while other efforts require retrofitting some businesses in order to use less energy.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Organic Burial
track.annotation: For those who are environmentally conscious, there's a popular way to "go green" when it comes to the end of life. Payne County will soon have the state's first "green burial" cemetery.

track.title: Oklahoma News Report
track.ov:subtitle: Kipp Middle School
track.annotation: Students at Kipp Middle School in Tulsa get life lessons by planting trees, creating rain gardens and learning how to “go green”.
